title: Edward Jenner - Wikipedia
author: Authority control
cleaned_text: Edward Jenner Edward Jenner |Born||17 May January 1823) was an English [physician](/wiki/Physician) and [scientist](/wiki/Scientist) who pioneered the concept of [vaccines](/wiki/Vaccine) and created the [smallpox vaccine](/wiki/Smallpox_vaccine), the world's first vaccine. [[2]](#cite_note-2) [[3]](#cite_note-Baxbydnb-3) The terms vaccine and vaccination are derived from Variolae vaccinae ('pustules of the cow'), the term devised by Jenner to denote [cowpox](/wiki/Cowpox). He used it in 1798 in the title of his Inquiry into the Variolae vaccinae known as the Cow Pox, in which he described the protective effect of cowpox against smallpox. [[4]](#cite_note-4) In the West, Jenner is often called "the father of [immunology](/wiki/Immunology)", [[5]](#cite_note-JennerBBC-5) and his work is said to have saved "more lives than any other man". [[6]](#cite_note-Baron1838_vol2-6): 100 [[7]](#cite_note-Telegraph-7) In Jenner's time, smallpox killed around 10% of global population, with the number as high as 20% in towns and cities where infection spread more easily. [[7]](#cite_note-Telegraph-7) In 1821, he was appointed physician to King [George IV](/wiki/George_IV_of_the_United_Kingdom), and was also made mayor of [Berkeley](/wiki/Berkeley,_Gloucestershire) and justice of the peace. He was a member of the [Royal Society](/wiki/Royal_Society). In the field of zoology, he was among the first modern scholars to describe the [brood parasitism](/wiki/Brood_parasitism) of the [cuckoo](/wiki/Common_cuckoo) ( [Aristotle](/wiki/Aristotle) also noted this behaviour in his [History of Animals](/wiki/History_of_Animals)). In 2002, Jenner was named in the [BBC](/wiki/BBC)'s list of the [100 Greatest Britons](/wiki/100_Greatest_Britons). Early life[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Edward_Jenner&action=edit§ion=1)] Edward Jenner 17 May 1749 [[8]](#cite_note-About_Edward_Jenner-8) in [Berkeley, Gloucestershire](/wiki/Berkeley,_Gloucestershire), England as the eighth of nine children. His father, the [Reverend](/wiki/The_Reverend) Stephen Jenner, was the [vicar](/wiki/Vicar) of Berkeley, so Jenner received a strong basic education. [[8]](#cite_note-About_Edward_Jenner-8) Education and training[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Edward_Jenner&action=edit§ion=2)] When he was young, he went to school in [Wotton-under-Edge](/wiki/Wotton-under-Edge) at Katherine Lady Berkeley's School and in [Cirencester](/wiki/Cirencester). [[8]](#cite_note-About_Edward_Jenner-8) During this time, he was [inoculated](/wiki/Inoculation) (by [variolation](/wiki/Variolation)) for [smallpox](/wiki/Smallpox), which had a lifelong effect upon his general health. [[8]](#cite_note-About_Edward_Jenner-8) At the age of 14, he was apprenticed for seven years to Daniel Ludlow, a [surgeon](/wiki/Surgeon) of [Chipping Sodbury](/wiki/Chipping_Sodbury), South Gloucestershire, where he gained most of the experience needed to become a surgeon himself. [[8]](#cite_note-About_Edward_Jenner-8) In 1770, aged 21, Jenner became apprenticed in surgery and anatomy under surgeon [John at [St George's Jenner [William Harvey](/wiki/William_Harvey)'s advice, well known in medical circles (and of the [Age of Enlightenment](/wiki/Age_of_Enlightenment)), "Don't think; try." with [natural history](/wiki/Natural_history) and proposed him for the [Royal Society](/wiki/Royal_Society). Returning to his native countryside by 1773, Jenner became a successful [family doctor](/wiki/General_practitioner) and surgeon, practising on dedicated premises at Berkeley. In 1792, "with twenty years' experience of general practice and surgery, Jenner obtained the degree of MD from the [University of St Andrews](/wiki/University_of_St_Andrews)". [[3]](#cite_note-Baxbydnb-3) Later life[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Edward_Jenner&action=edit§ion=3)] Jenner and others formed the Fleece Medical Society or Gloucestershire Medical Society, so called because it met in the parlour of the Fleece Inn, [Rodborough](/wiki/Rodborough), Gloucestershire. Members dined together and read papers on medical subjects. Jenner contributed papers on [angina pectoris](/wiki/Angina_pectoris), [ophthalmia](/wiki/Ophthalmia), and cardiac valvular disease and commented on [cowpox](/wiki/Cowpox). He also belonged to a similar society which met in [Alveston](/wiki/Alveston), near Bristol. [[11]](#cite_note-11) He became a master [mason](/wiki/Freemasonry) on 30 December 1802, in Lodge of Faith and Friendship #449. From 1812 to 1813, he served as worshipful master of Royal Berkeley Lodge of Faith and Friendship. [[12]](#cite_note-12) Zoology[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Edward_Jenner&action=edit§ion=4)] Jenner was elected fellow of the [Royal Society](/wiki/Royal_Society) in 1788, following his publication of a careful study of the previously misunderstood life of the nested [cuckoo](/wiki/Common_cuckoo), a study that combined observation, experiment, and dissection. Jenner described how the newly hatched cuckoo pushed its host's eggs and fledgling chicks out of the nest (contrary to existing belief that the adult cuckoo did it). [[13]](#cite_note-13) Having observed this behaviour, Jenner demonstrated an anatomical adaptation for it - the baby cuckoo has a depression in its back, not present after 12 days of life, that enables it to cup eggs and other chicks. The adult does not remain long enough in the area to perform this task. Jenner's findings were published in [Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society](/wiki/Philosophical_Transactions_of_the_Royal_Society) in 1788. [[14]](#cite_note-14) [[15]](#cite_note-15) "The singularity of its shape is well adapted to these purposes; for, different from other newly hatched birds, its back from the scapula downwards is very broad, with a considerable depression in the middle. This depression seems formed by nature for the design of giving a more secure lodgement to the egg of the Hedge-sparrow, or its young one, when the young Cuckoo is employed in removing either of them from the nest. When it is about twelve days old, this cavity is quite filled up, and then the back assumes the shape of nestling birds in general." [[16]](#cite_note-16) Jenner's nephew assisted in the study. He was born on 30 June 1737. Jenner's understanding of the cuckoo's behaviour was not entirely believed until the artist [Jemima Blackburn](/wiki/Jemima_Blackburn), a keen observer of birdlife, saw a blind nestling pushing out a host's egg. Blackburn's description and illustration were enough to convince [Charles Darwin](/wiki/Charles_Darwin) to revise a later edition of [On the Origin of Species](/wiki/On_the_Origin_of_Species). [[17]](#cite_note-17) Jenner's interest in zoology played a large role in his first experiment with inoculation. Not only did he have a profound understanding of human anatomy due to his medical training, but he also understood animal biology and its role in human-animal trans-species boundaries in disease transmission. At the time, there was no way of knowing how important this connection would be to the history and discovery of vaccinations. We see this connection now; many present-day vaccinations include animal parts from cows, rabbits, and chicken eggs, which can be attributed to the work of Jenner and his cowpox/smallpox vaccination. [[18]](#cite_note-18) Marriage and human medicine[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Edward_Jenner&action=edit§ion=5)] Jenner married Catherine Kingscote (who died in 1815 from [tuberculosis](/wiki/Tuberculosis)) in March 1788. He might have met her while he and other fellows were experimenting with [balloons](/wiki/Balloons). Jenner's trial balloon descended into [Kingscote Park, Gloucestershire](/wiki/Kingscote_Park,_Gloucestershire), owned by Catherine's father Anthony Kingscote. [[19]](#cite_note-19) had three children: (1789-1810), Robert Fitzharding (1792-1854) and Catherine (1794-1833). [[20]](#cite_note-20) He earned his MD from the [University of St Andrews](/wiki/University_of_St_Andrews) in 1792. [[21]](#cite_note-21) He is credited with advancing the understanding of [angina pectoris](/wiki/Angina_pectoris). [[22]](#cite_note-22) In his correspondence with Heberden, he wrote: "How much the heart must suffer from the coronary arteries not being able to perform their functions". [[23]](#cite_note-23) Invention of the vaccine[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Edward_Jenner&action=edit§ion=6)] [Inoculation](/wiki/Inoculation) was already a standard practice in Asian and African medicine but involved serious risks, including the possibility that those inoculated would become contagious and spread the disease to others. [[24]](#cite_note-24) In 1721, [Lady Mary Wortley Montagu](/wiki/Lady_Mary_Wortley_Montagu) had imported [variolation](/wiki/Variolation) to Britain after having observed it in [Istanbul](/wiki/Istanbul). While [Johnnie Notions](/wiki/Johnnie_Notions) had great success with his self-devised inoculation [[25]](#cite_note-Smith1998-25) (and was reputed not to have lost a single patient), [[26]](#cite_note-Dishington1999-26) his method's practice was limited to the [Shetland Isles](/wiki/Shetland). [Voltaire](/wiki/Voltaire) wrote that at this time 60% of the population caught smallpox and 20% of the population died from it. [[27]](#cite_note-27) Voltaire also states that the [Circassians](/wiki/Circassia) used the inoculation from times immemorial, and the custom may have been borrowed by the Turks from the Circassians. [[28]](#cite_note-28) In 1766, Daniel Bernoulli analysed smallpox morbidity and [mortality](/wiki/Mortality_rate) data to demonstrate the efficacy of inoculation. [[29]](#cite_note-29) By 1768, English physician [John Fewster](/wiki/John_Fewster) had realised that prior infection with cowpox rendered a person immune to smallpox. [[30]](#cite_note-30) [[31]](#cite_note-31) In the years following 1770, at least five investigators in England and Germany (Sevel, Jensen, Jesty 1774, Rendell, Plett 1791) successfully tested in humans a cowpox vaccine against smallpox. [[32]](#cite_note-PlettSudhoffs-32) For example, [Dorset](/wiki/Dorset) farmer [Benjamin [[33]](#cite_note-33) successfully vaccinated and presumably [induced immunity](/wiki/Artificial_induction_of_immunity) with cowpox in his wife and two children during a smallpox epidemic in 1774, but it was not until Jenner's work that the procedure became widely understood. Jenner may have been aware of Jesty's procedures and success. [[34]](#cite_note-34) A similar observation was later made in France by [Jacques Antoine Rabaut-Pommier](/wiki/Jacques_Antoine_Rabaut-Pommier) in 1780. [[35]](#cite_note-35) Jenner postulated that the in the blisters that affected individuals affected by [cowpox](/wiki/Cowpox) (a disease similar to smallpox, but much less virulent) protected them from smallpox. On 14 May 1796, Jenner tested his hypothesis by inoculating [James Phipps](/wiki/James_Phipps), an eight-year-old boy who was the son of Jenner's gardener. He scraped pus from cowpox blisters on the hands of Sarah Nelmes, a milkmaid who had caught cowpox from a cow called Blossom, [[36]](#cite_note-JennerMuseum-36) whose hide now hangs on the wall of the [St. George's Medical School](/wiki/St_George%27s,_University_of_London) library (now in [Tooting](/wiki/Tooting)). Phipps was the 17th case described in Jenner's first paper on [vaccination](/wiki/Vaccination). [[37]](#cite_note-37) |Jenner's Hypothesis:| |The initial source of infection was a disease of horses, called "the grease", which was transferred to cattle by farm workers, transformed, and then manifested as cowpox.| Jenner inoculated Phipps in both arms that day, subsequently producing in Phipps a fever and some uneasiness, but no full-blown infection. Later, he injected Phipps with [variolous material](/wiki/Variolation), the routine method of immunization at that time. No disease followed. The boy was later challenged with variolous material and again showed no sign of infection. No unexpected side effects occurred, and neither Phipps nor any other recipients underwent any future 'breakthrough' cases. Jenner's biographer [John Baron](/wiki/John_Baron_(physician)) would later speculate that Jenner understood one could be inoculated against smallpox by being exposed to cowpox by observing the unblemished complexion of milkmaids, rather than building on the work of his predecessors. The milkmaids story is still widely repeated even though it appears to be a myth. [[38]](#cite_note-38) [[39]](#cite_note-39) |Known:| |Smallpox is more dangerous less dangerous than variolation.| |Hypothesis:| |If target is infected with cowpox, then target is immune to smallpox.| |Test:| |If variolation after infection with cowpox fails to produce a smallpox infection, immunity to smallpox has been achieved.| |Consequence:| |Immunity to smallpox can be induced much more safely than by variolation.| Donald Hopkins has written, "Jenner's unique contribution was not that he inoculated a few persons with cowpox, but that he then proved [by subsequent challenges] that they were immune to smallpox. Moreover, he demonstrated that the protective cowpox pus could be effectively inoculated from person to person, not just directly from cattle." [[40]](#cite_note-Hopkins-40) Jenner successfully tested his hypothesis on 23 additional subjects. Jenner continued his research and reported it to the [Royal Society](/wiki/Royal_Society), which did not publish the initial paper. After revisions and further investigations, he published his findings on the 23 cases, including his 11-month-old son Robert. [[41]](#cite_note-41) Some of his conclusions were correct, some erroneous; modern microbiological and microscopic methods would make his studies easier to reproduce. The medical establishment deliberated at length over his findings before accepting them. Eventually, vaccination was accepted, and in 1840, the British government banned variolation - the use of smallpox to induce immunity - and provided vaccination using cowpox free of charge (see [Vaccination Act](/wiki/Vaccination_Act)). The success of his discovery soon spread around Europe and was used en masse in the Spanish [Balmis Expedition](/wiki/Balmis_Expedition) (1803-1806), a three-year-long mission to the Americas, the Philippines, Macao, China, led by [Francisco Javier de Balmis](/wiki/Francisco_Javier_de_Balmis) with the aim of giving thousands the smallpox vaccine. [[42]](#cite_note-42) The expedition was successful, and Jenner wrote: "I don't imagine the annals of history furnish an example of philanthropy so noble, so extensive as this". [[43]](#cite_note-43) [Napoleon](/wiki/Napoleon), who at the time was [at war with Britain](/wiki/Napoleonic_Wars), had all his French troops vaccinated, awarded Jenner a medal, and at the request of Jenner, he released two English prisoners of war and permitted their return home. [[44]](#cite_note-Napoleon-44) [[45]](#cite_note-45) Napoleon remarked he could not "refuse anything to one of the greatest benefactors of mankind". [[44]](#cite_note-Napoleon-44) Jenner's continuing work on vaccination prevented him from continuing his ordinary medical practice. He was supported by his colleagues and the King in petitioning [Parliament](/wiki/UK_Parliament), [[46]](#cite_note-46) and was granted £10,000 in 1802 for his work on vaccination. [[47]](#cite_note-DNB1892-47) In 1807, he was granted another £20,000 after the Royal College of Physicians confirmed the widespread efficacy of vaccination. [[3]](#cite_note-Baxbydnb-3) Later life[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Edward_Jenner&action=edit§ion=7)] Jenner was later elected a foreign honorary member of the [American Academy of Arts and Sciences](/wiki/American_Academy_of_Arts_and_Sciences) in 1802, a member of the [American Philosophical Society](/wiki/American_Philosophical_Society) in 1804, [[48]](#cite_note-48) and a foreign member of the [Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences](/wiki/Royal_Swedish_Academy_of_Sciences) in 1806. [[49]](#cite_note-AAAS-49) In 1803 in London, he became president of the Jennerian Society, concerned with promoting vaccination to eradicate [smallpox](/wiki/Smallpox). The Jennerian ceased operations in 1809. Jenner became a member of the Medical and Chirurgical Society on its founding in 1805 (now the [Royal Society of Medicine](/wiki/Royal_Society_of_Medicine)) and presented several papers there. In 1808, with government aid, the National Vaccine Establishment was founded, but Jenner felt dishonoured by the men selected to run it and resigned his directorship. [[6]](#cite_note-Baron1838_vol2-6): 122-125 Returning to London in 1811, Jenner observed a significant number of cases of smallpox after vaccination. He found that in these cases the severity of the illness was notably diminished by previous vaccination. In 1821, he was appointed physician extraordinary to [King George IV](/wiki/King_George_IV), and was also made mayor of Berkeley [[3]](#cite_note-Baxbydnb-3) and [magistrate](/wiki/Magistrate_(England_and_Wales)) [[6]](#cite_note-Baron1838_vol2-6): 303 ( [justice of the peace](/wiki/Justice_of_the_peace)). He continued to investigate natural history, and in 1823, the last year of his life, he presented his "Observations on the Migration of Birds" to the Royal [[51]](#cite_note-51) in a state of [apoplexy](/wiki/Apoplexy) on 25 January 1823, with his right side paralysed. [[6]](#cite_note-Baron1838_vol2-6): 314 He did not recover and died the next day of an apparent stroke, his second, on 26 January 1823, [[6]](#cite_note-Baron1838_vol2-6) aged 73. He was buried in the family vault at the Church of St Mary, Berkeley. [[52]](#cite_note-52) Religious views[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Edward_Jenner&action=edit§ion=9)] Neither fanatic nor lax, [[53]](#cite_note-53) Jenner was a Christian who in his personal correspondence showed himself quite spiritual. [[6]](#cite_note-Baron1838_vol2-6): 141 Some days before his death, he stated to a friend: "I am not surprised that men are not grateful to me; but I wonder that they are not grateful to God for the good which He has made me the instrument of conveying to my fellow creatures". [[6]](#cite_note-Baron1838_vol2-6): 295 Legacy[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Edward_Jenner&action=edit§ion=10)] In 1980, the [World Health Organization](/wiki/World_Health_Organization) declared smallpox an eradicated disease. [[54]](#cite_note-54) This was the result of coordinated public health efforts, but vaccination was an essential component. Although the disease was declared eradicated, some pus samples still remain in laboratories in [Centers for Disease Control and Prevention](/wiki/Centers_for_Disease_Control_and_Prevention) in [Atlanta](/wiki/Atlanta) in the US, and in [State Research Center of Virology and Biotechnology VECTOR](/wiki/State_Research_Center_of_Virology_and_Biotechnology_VECTOR) in [Koltsovo, Novosibirsk Oblast](/wiki/Koltsovo,_Novosibirsk_Oblast), Russia. [[55]](#cite_note-55) Jenner's vaccine laid the foundation for contemporary discoveries in [immunology](/wiki/Immunology). [[56]](#cite_note-JennerEssortment-56) In 2002, Jenner was named in the [BBC](/wiki/BBC)'s list of the [100 Greatest Britons](/wiki/100_Greatest_Britons) following a UK-wide vote. [[57]](#cite_note-57) Commemorated on postage stamps issued by the [Royal Mail](/wiki/Royal_Mail), in 1999 he featured in their [World honour. [[59]](#cite_note-59) Monuments and buildings[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Edward_Jenner&action=edit§ion=11)] - Jenner's house in the of [Berkeley, Gloucestershire](/wiki/Berkeley,_Gloucestershire), is now a [small museum](/wiki/Edward_Jenner_Museum), [[3]](#cite_note-Baxbydnb-3)housing, among other things, the horns of the cow, Blossom. - A statue of Jenner by [Robert William Sievier](/wiki/Robert_William_Sievier)was in the - Near the Gloucestershire village of [Uley](/wiki/Uley), Downham Hill is locally known as "Smallpox Hill" for its possible role in Jenner's studies of the disease. [[62]](#cite_note-62) - London's [St. George's Hospital Medical School](/wiki/St._George%27s_Hospital_Medical_School)has a Jenner Pavilion, where his bust may be found. [[63]](#cite_note-StGeorgesHistory-63) - A group of villages in [Somerset County, Pennsylvania](/wiki/Somerset_County,_Pennsylvania), United States, was named in Jenner's honour by early 19th-century English settlers, [Edward Jenner Institute for Vaccine Research](/wiki/Edward_Jenner_Institute_for_Vaccine_Research)is an infectious disease vaccine research centre, also the [Jenner Institute](/wiki/Jenner_Institute)part of the [University of Oxford](/wiki/University_of_Oxford). - A section at [Gloucestershire Royal Hospital](/wiki/Gloucestershire_Royal_Hospital)is known as the Edward Jenner Unit; it is where blood is drawn. [[66]](#cite_note-66) - A ward at [Northwick Park Hospital](/wiki/Northwick_Park_Hospital)is called Jenner Ward. [[67]](#cite_note-67) - Jenner Gardens at Cheltenham, Gloucestershire, opposite one of the scientist's former offices, is a small garden and cemetery. [[68]](#cite_note-68) - A statue of Jenner was erected at the [Tokyo National Museum](/wiki/Tokyo_National_Museum)in 1896 to commemorate the centenary of Jenner's discovery of vaccination. [[69]](#cite_note-69) - A monument outside the walls of the upper town of [Boulogne sur Mer](/wiki/Boulogne_sur_Mer), France. [[70]](#cite_note-70) - A street N16 [51°3331N around 1970, The Jenner Health Centre, 201 Stanstead Road, Forest Hill, London, SE23 1HU [[71]](#cite_note-71) - Jenner's name is featured on the Frieze of the [London School of Hygiene & Tropical Medicine](/wiki/London_School_of_Hygiene_%26_Tropical_Medicine). Twenty-three names of public health and tropical medicine pioneers were chosen to feature on the Keppel Street building when it was constructed in 1926. [[72]](#cite_note-72) - Minor planet [5168 Jenner](/wiki/5168_Jenner)is named in his honour. [[73]](#cite_note-73) Publications[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Edward_Jenner&action=edit§ion=12)] - 1798 [An Inquiry Into the Causes and Effects of the Variolæ Vaccinæ](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/An_Inquiry_Into_the_Causes_and_Effects_of_the_Variol%C3%A6_Vaccin%C3%A6) - 1799 Further Observations on the Variolæ Vaccinæ, or Cow-Pox. [[74]](#cite_note-74) - 1800 A Continuation of Facts and Observations relative to the Variolæ Vaccinæ 40pgs [[75]](#cite_note-75) - 1801 January 2015.
